title: Catch Sunshine in a Bottle with the 8 Best Vitamin D Supplements of 2022
author: Lauren Armstrong; RDN
cleaned_text: We include products we think are useful for our readers. If you buy through links on this page, we may earn a small commission [Here's our process](/product-selection-process). Greatist only shows you brands and products that we stand behind.Our team thoroughly researches and evaluates the recommendations we make on our site. To establish that the product manufacturers addressed safety and efficacy standards, we: - Evaluate ingredients and composition: Do they have the potential to cause harm? - Fact-check all health claims: Do they align with the current body of scientific evidence? - Assess the brand: Does it operate with integrity and adhere to industry best practices? Are you getting enough D? (Ummm, we mean [vitamin D](/health/vitamin-d).) Well you better check because you need it for [calcium](/health/surprising-dairy-free-sources-of-calcium) and phosphorus absorption, bone health, and [muscle growth](/fitness/how-much-muscle-can-you-gain-in-a-month) and development. Your bod makes vitamin D when exposed to [sunlight](/discover/sun-lamp) (and you can get it from [some foods](/health/foods-with-minerals)), but sometimes you still might not get enough. In fact, [about 1 billion people worldwide](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532266/) have a vitamin D deficiency. And about 50 percent of the population has an insufficiency (meaning they don't have a full deficiency, but they're definitely not getting enough vitamin D). If you need more vitamin D in your life, you can take an over-the-counter supplement. Not sure which one to choose? We got you — here's a list of the best vitamin D supplements to take when the sun just ain't cutting it. 8 best vitamin D supplements of 2022 - Best vitamin D and multivitamin combo: Chewable](#garden) Knowing that this is something you're going to be putting in your bod, we held our picks to high standards. Here are the criteria we used: Quality We put all the products through a rigorous medical and business vetting process. This process checks whether companies are doing anything shady (like saying its products cure certain diseases), whether their products use evidence-based ingredients, and whether they've received any FDA/FTC warning letters. We included products only from companies that passed this process and have strict standards for quality and purity. Nutrient bioavailability There are actually two forms of vitamin D — D2 (ergocalciferol) and D3 (cholecalciferol). The only difference is in the chemical side chains, but both are well absorbed [in your gut](/live/good-gut-health). Supplements can be made with either D2 or D3, but [most research shows](https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/british-journal-of-nutrition/article/longterm-vitamin-d3-supplementation-is-more-effective-than-vitamin-d2-in-maintaining-serum-25hydroxyvitamin-d-status-over-the-winter-months/A6CD4FE5C649E0FAC9BCBAFB23538707) that vitamin D3 increases the level of vitamin D in your blood to a greater extent and for longer than D2 does. For that reason, we only included vitamin D3 supplements. Reviews [Supplements](/eat/what-you-should-know-about-supplements) are a dime a dozen — one Google search will show you thousands to choose from. We chose products that had great reviews from A LOT of people. Pricing guide - $ = under $15 - $$ = $15-$20 - $$$ = over $20 Best vitamin D and multivitamin combo [Ritual Essential Multivitamin Capsule — 60 count](https://activation.healthline.com/api/member-offers/4333/redirect?lp=328&tc=120226&subid2=%2Fgr8%2Fhealth%2Fbest-vitamin-d-supplement&subid=ritual_multivitamingrid_hl_vms_4551&correlationId=null) - Price: $$$ - Supplement type: capsule Instead of being jam-packed with every [vitamin and mineral](/eat/one-day-menu-for-nutrients) under the sun, this multivitamin was developed to fill nutrient gaps according to your sex and age. The company's motto is "less is more" — so you aren't getting unnecessary nutrients that you're likely getting plenty of from the [food you eat](/eat/vegan-vitamin-d). Considerations: Before taking any supplement, it's important to check with a healthcare professional. If they've given you a thumbs-up on a vitamin D supplement, but you want to go with a multivitamin combo, get another thumbs-up for the rest of the vitamins included in this all-in-one option. How to take it: Take 2 capsules per day to get 2,000 IU (50 micrograms [mcg]) of vitamin D. Plus, it's made without [gluten](/eat/gluten-free-diet-what-is-it-really), [soy](/health/foods-that-kill-testosterone), or GMOs. Since vitamin D is fat-soluble, consuming it with a fatty meal can help your body absorb the vitamin. A [2015 study](https://www.jandonline.org/article/S2212-2672(14)01468-3/fulltext) found that plasma vitamin D3 levels were 32 percent greater in people who took the supplement with a [fat-containing meal](/health/superfood-avocado) compared to a fat-free meal. This specific supplement is infused with [coconut oil](/health/refined-vs-unrefined-coconut-oil), so the fat comes along with it! Considerations: Although the addition of [coconut oil](/health/coconut-oil-detox) can help with absorption, it also means that folks with an allergy to tree nuts may need to choose a different D3 supplement. If you're allergic to nuts, steer clear unless your doctor gives the OK. How to take it: Take 1 softgel per day, which provides 5,000 IU (125 mcg) of vitamin D. Even the raspberry-lemon flavor is created with organic flavoring and without added sugar or artificial sweetener. Considerations: The quantity is on the small side. With only a 30-day supply, you'll need to reorder more often. How to take it: Chew 1 tablet daily, which will give you 5,000 IU (50 mcg) of vitamin D. [The sun](/health/how-to-tan-safely) doesn't shine all the time, and it's possible you don't always get enough vitamin D from food. If you live in a place where it rains, sleets, and snows, it's not always possible to get enough vitamin D from the sun. Certain individuals and populations are also at greater risk of vitamin D deficiency, including: - older adults - people with higher body weight - people in nursing homes or hospitals - people with dark skin tones Another challenge: Your body needs UVB radiation in order to absorb sunlight and convert it to usable vitamin D3. UV radiation is considered a carcinogen and is one of the biggest reasons for [skin cancer](/health/melanoma). [Sunscreen](/health/best-sunscreen/) reduces your UV exposure, which reduces your risk of cancer but also blocks some vitamin D-producing UV rays. Signs of deficiency If you have a vitamin D deficiency, your body will give you a heads-up. Some common symptoms you may notice if your levels are too low are: - frequent illness [tiredness](/health/all-i-want-to-do-is-sleep) - bone and muscle pain [depression](/health/stages-of-depression) - bone loss [hair loss](/health/thinning-hair) But many of these symptoms could have other causes, so getting your blood levels checked can determine whether you have a deficiency. Other vitamin D benefits Vitamin D's benefits go beyond bone health. A [2018 review](https://www.mdpi.com/1422-0067/19/8/2419/htm) found that vitamin D could potentially protect against [the flu virus](/health/vitamin-d-coronavirus). Vitamin D is also important for a healthy pregnancy. Some [research](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jmwh.13014) suggests that vitamin D deficiency during pregnancy is associated with preeclampsia and preterm birth. Before diving into the world of vitamin D supplementation, consult a healthcare professional and get your blood levels tested. This is the only way you'll know if you have a vitamin D deficiency. From there, a pro will be able to determine a dose that's ideal for you. You may have noticed that all the vitamin D supplements on this list surpass the recommended intakes we mentioned earlier. There's also a daily upper limit of [100 mcg (4,000 IU)](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/VitaminD-Consumer/#:~:text=Excess%20vitamin%20D%20can%20also,and%20lactating%20teens%20and%20women.) for children over 9 years old, adults, and folks who are pregnant or breastfeeding. A severe deficiency sometimes requires a larger dose at first, followed by maintenance dosage. When you browse this list or go shopping for a vitamin D supplement, consider your specific needs. Do you prefer capsules, gummies, or liquid? There are a bunch of options, so pick one that works with your current routine and preferences. It's also important to pay close attention to ingredients so you don't choose a product that contains something you're allergic to or that you avoid for personal reasons. Third-party certifications from organizations like [United States Pharmacopeia](https://www.usp.org/) and [NSF International](https://www.nsf.org/certified-products-systems) are a bonus! So, what's the best way to take vitamin D supplements? Even if a supplement says you can take it on an empty stomach, vitamin D seems to do best with a meal. This is especially true when it's paired with a meal higher in fat. [One study](https://www.jandonline.org/article/S2212-2672(14)01468-3/fulltext) found that adults who took vitamin D with a fat-heavy meal had a 32 percent boost in vitamin D blood levels after 12 hours compared with those taking the supp with a fat-free meal. Should you take vitamin D morning, noon, or night? Honestly, it's up to you and your preferences. There seems to be no "ideal" time, although some [research](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6232868/) claims it may be best to take in the morning rather than at night. That's because increased vitamin D levels may suppress [melatonin](/health/natural-sleep-aids), the hormone responsible for regulating your [snooze cycle](https://www.healthline.com/health/waking-up-in-the-middle-of-the-night). If you're [pregnant](/health/things-not-to-do-while-pregnant), vitamin D is usually recommended as part of your daily supplement routine. You should confirm with your doctor how much is safe for you specifically. Recommended Dietary Allowances for vitamin D - age 12 months or younger: [400 IU (10 mcg)](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/VitaminD-HealthProfessional/) - ages 1 to 13: 600 IU (15 mcg) - ages 14 to 70: 600 IU (15 mcg) - age 70 or older: 800 IU (20 mcg) When your body needs vitamin D and you're taking the proper dosage, chances are you won't experience any side effects. On the other hand, because vitamin D is fat-soluble (which means your body stores the excess if you take too much, rather than peeing it out), taking too much in the long term can cause excessive buildup in your body and lead to some unwanted side effects. These could include: - nausea - vomiting - poor appetite - stomach pain - constipation or diarrhea - bone loss - kidney problems TL;DR: Always talk with a healthcare pro before starting a vitamin D supplement (or any supplement, really). If you're not ready to hop on the supplement train, you can get vitamin D from food and sunshine (although it's a little more complicated). Not many foods naturally contain vitamin D, but according to the [National Institutes of Health](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/VitaminD-HealthProfessional/), fatty fish and fish oils are among the best sources. The top three food sources of vitamin D are: - cod liver oil: 1,360 IU (34 mcg) per tablespoon - rainbow trout: IU (16.2 mcg) per 3 ounces - sockeye salmon: 570 IU (14.2 mcg) per 3 ounces Your skin also absorbs UV rays from the sun and converts them into vitamin D. The amount you get depends on time of day, cloud coverage, skin melanin, and [sunscreen](/health/best-sunscreen-sprays). Some experts say that getting outdoors between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. for [5 to 30 minutes](https://ods.od.nih.gov/factsheets/VitaminD-HealthProfessional/) twice per week will lead to sufficient vitamin D synthesis. If the sun ain't shining (or you're a stay-in-the-shade type), a vitamin D supplement can be a super effective way to meet your daily needs. Just remember to check with a healthcare pro before you start taking a vitamin D supplement to get the A-OK and figure out what dosage you need. Once you confirm that you definitely need the D (), you can use our rec list as your starting point for finding the supp that suits you best.
